title: What will be China's year-on-year GDP growth rate for the second quarter of 2021?
preds: time decay: ready to trim tails

We expect China’s economy to continue to recover, and we maintain our 2021 GDP forecast at 8.8%." https://assets.kpmg/content/dam/kpmg/cn/pdf/en/2021/05/china-economic-monitor-q2-2021.pdf This is enough to bump up bin E 7 points to 70/30 split.

Still think that most estimates in this question are underestimating variation around what appear to be reasonable assumptions as to the mean - it is an uncertain time, and growth predictions have been widely off the mark in recent times *

The average y/y growth rate for China is expected by economists to be 6.1% for Q2 2021 (this is the statistic that the question refers to not annualized growth). Though the Chinese economy did amazing well y/y in Q1 2021 (118.1) this was due to the large drop in Q1 2020. Even if growth were the same from Q1 to Q2 then the growth would still not be nearly as robust in y/y terms because the growth references the previous quarter in the previous year not the annualized growth for the year or the growth between quarters. Still seems most likely to be ~6.5%. https://www.reuters.com/world/china/view-4-chinas-q1-gdp-grows-record-pace-recovery-speeds-up-2021-04-16/#:~:text=%22We%20expect%20GDP%20will%20slow,%2C%20coming%20in%20at%208.6%25

Update -  "We expect GDP will slow to 6.1% y/y in Q2-21, and average 5.5% y/y in the remainder of 2021, below the official growth target of 6.0%. However, due to the large base effect in Q1-21, we expect that annualised growth will comfortably exceed the official target, coming in at 8.6%. https://www.reuters.com/world/china/view-4-chinas-q1-gdp-grows-record-pace-recovery-speeds-up-2021-04-16/#:~:text=%22We%20expect%20GDP%20will%20slow,%2C%20coming%20in%20at%208.6%25. Expected 8.6% - enough for me to bump up bin E 3 points.

Important to note is that China compares its GDP growth against the same quarter previous year, unlike the US which  reports growth on an annualized base, or the EU which reports it against the previous quarter. (1) The surge seen in Q1 2021 had less to do with strong demand and more with being compared with a lackluster Q1 2020. Quarter on quarter growth slowed down to 0,6% growth. Also, growth between Q2 2020 and Q3 2020 and between Q3 2020 and Q4 2020 was at 3,1% and 3,2 almost double the pre Covid average  (2). This shows a lot of rebound growth happened in 2020 already. Higher growth in Q2 2020 also means a stronger baseline to compare Q2021 with.  Growth figures for April 2021 show a slowdown in year on year growth but still point to a large expansion. (3)  1:
https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2021/04/17/is-growth-in-china-soaring-or-slowing

BLUF: I assess it is very likely china will report Q2-2021 Year over Year GDP growth greater than 8.0% based upon Q1-2021 reporting and historical post recession GDP growth rates. Base rate appears to be in the 6-7% range - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_GDP_of_China#Quarterly_GDP But if one accepts we are in a recovery phase - like after the "Great Recession" China's year-on-year GDP growth rate in 2010 and 2011 was consistently >8%. Q1-2021 appears to be a 18%+ YoY increase - probably driven by pent up demand as indicated by an above average current account balance. - https://www.ceicdata.com/en/indicator/china/current-account-balance So the historical data points towards the 5-8% range being par.  But the variable of, "the world coming out of the COVID-19" should contribute positively to above average growth for at least 2-quarters. - See 2010 and 2011 quarterly gdp yoy growth rates - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_GDP_of_China#Quarterly_GDP

China's GDP grew by 18.3 percent year-on-year in the first quarter of 2021.
Excepting something within that range for Q2 (also seen the years before). 
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-14/what-to-watch-for-in-china-s-unprecedented-gdp-growth-report

While Q1 growth of 18.3% has a large base effect embedded in it and also has benefitted greatly from sharp rebound in domestic consumption, the momentum is likely to weaken somewhat but still be enough to make 8% or higher a strong probability for Q2.
With 1st quarter growth at more than 18%, there is no reason to think the Chinese economy will slow down in the 2nd quarter.

It's important to understand that China's growth target is less about the reality of the economy, and more about what China is willing to do to make the numbers match up. China has historically kept up with their GDP growth targets on a consistent basis. China abandoned the growth target for 2020 and is claiming that their current target for 2021 (6%) is very easy to reach. Therefore, it's very likely that the published numbers will be a little above 6%.
I think the answer is already known

Tweaking. Generally growth has been 6-7%. Q1 will be impacted heavily by base effects. Suspect Q2 will be much less impacted. But some upside from opening up globally. Further lockdown seems unlikely so downside risks harder to see.

The previous 3 quarters of growth equal 7% already (1.031*1.032*1.006), so unless the economy shrinks in Q2 that would mean 7% is the lowest it could be YoY. I anticipate no reason for the economy to shrink, though given that the previous QoQ growth was only 0.6% it raises some questions. Anything above ~1% QoQ growth in Q2 would take us to the last bucket, and 1% doesn't sound too unreasonable.

Reducing confidence in over 8% a bit, making 7 to 8 more likely. Q2 has grown over 11% for the past 4 years over Q1 in nominal value. If Q2 2021 were to grow by 11% that would result in about 10.6% growth over Q2 2020 in nominal terms. But accounting for inflation makes things more complicated, if inflation reduces that value by 2.6% or greater it would no longer exceed 8%, which seems plausible to me. Some scratch work with China's GDP numbers: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1znPsbGpPwrgZrtv7z5ZNG6NT9OZgGtRk4sSv7JbmyWk/edit?usp=sharing

China had its biggest COVID shock in Q1 so recovery from Q2 is not likely to be quite as extreme as Q1 where January was particularly affected.
If growth rates historically were about 6pc and last year at 4pc and this year underlying is 6pc then growth year on year should be about 8pc (based on my simplistic approach).  So forecasting for a slightly higher rate that I think the underlying real growth is month on month.

Q4 2020 numbers came out as 6.5% increase year over year. Based on that I'm increasing confidence in Q2 being over 8%. Comparing nominal GDP numbers to the index China has reported I'm estimating that inflation is low, which makes sense when coming out of a recession, so that shouldn't be subtracting from the nominal growth numbers too much. In a normal year Q2 is generally about 4.5% to 6.3% below the GDP of the previous Q4. Even if Q2 2021 is 6.3% below Q4 2020 the GDP for Q2 2021 would be 27.76 trillion yuan, which would be about 11% over the GDP for Q2 2020 of 25.01 trillion yuan. That's before inflation, so inflation would deduct a bit from that, but with fairly low inflation coming out of the recession it's hard to see inflation exceeding 3%. FRED series showing Q4 2020 GDP in Yuan: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CHNGDPNQDSMEI#0 Chinese data showing 106.5 index over the previous year for Q4 2020: http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/Statisticaldata/nsdp/201508/t20150819_1232260.html Some messy scratch work playing with the GDP numbers to estimate growth for second quarter: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1znPsbGpPwrgZrtv7z5ZNG6NT9OZgGtRk4sSv7JbmyWk/edit?usp=sharing

2020 Q4 was 6.5pc.
If we think 2021 Q2 will be compared to the Q last year that made the most contraction then we have underlying growth plus the net depression of last year to account which may push up numbers.  So think top and bottom bins unlikely.  Spreading assessment across others

Now that the question is focused around rate (and not growth target) the probabilities shift greatly. The Chinese economy seems to have been doing fairly well especially with respect to other economies because more stringent (draconian) Chinese measures at halting the spread of COVID seem to have worked in some part. Nevertheless, the Chinese economy has two major issues waying it down which will keep the growth rate from being above 7.0% in my view. First, the large amount of privately held debt (as much as %188 of GDP per the IMF: https://www.imf.org/external/datamapper/PVD_LS@GDD/CHN). Second, the semi-export focus of the current Chinese economy and the desire by the regime to increase the ratio of domestic to foreign consumption of Chinese products (https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/voa-news-china/china-plans-lift-economy-boosting-consumption#:~:text=Consumption%20growth,manufacturing%2Doriented%20economy%20remain%20stable.) As domestic consumption can only grow slowly compared to growing export focus (growing domestic consumption requires growing internal wealth which takes time vs. selling exports to gain wealth from other countries' consumers which already have it).  Thus, Chinese growth will be relatively strong, but not spectular compared to previous years (i.e., above 6% but below 8%).

Q IV year-on-year 2019 to 2020 was 6.5% up. They are back on track (or at least the numbers they report are). That was from a strong quarter to the last one in the 2020-pandemic. The base for this question is the second-worst quarter for decades. Will it go up MORE than those 6.5%? Yes, most probably. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-18/china-s-economy-grew-2-3-in-2020-accelerating-global-rise

Update. Decreased change of 7 to 8% growth. Although this is the official target I think my previous forecast was a little to optimistic. Growth in q4 2020, and 2020 overall, was mainly export driven. With the rest of the world slowly returning to normal due to vaccination I expect the growth potential of export to return to normal levels (which, all else being equal would result in 5 to 6% growth as expected for 2021 before 2020).
Consumer spending is still lagging while increasingly important for the economic growth.

Considerations:
- If you google "china gdp growth 2021" almost everyone seems to agree, that it will be above 8% for the whole year 2021. Most of that growth will result from a rebound after a horrible QI 2020 and a bad QII 2020. This question is about a comparison between QII 2020 and QII 2021. 
- 6% would have been a "normal" year.
- China has the pandemic under control, and it´s number reporting is generally very politically motivated. I think the crowd expects too little growth here.

But in recent years inflation has slowed in China, and I'm finding that in the last couple years inflation has been around 1 to 2%. So keeping that in mind I'm reducing confidence in the last two buckets a bit. Original reasoning with reply on how to find data: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212574

Q2 2020 had a very low growth rate of 3.2%. Even if China grows by 7% overall in 2021, the growth in Q2 2021 will be likely more than 8% due to low base effect.

Official target for 2021 is 8% so I assume a lot of policy and GDP reporting will be targeted at reaching this level. I also assume it more likely that GDP will be slightly below target given the fact that it is higher that what China's economy managed the last few years. Most ways to increase GDP are getting harder to control for the government. Consumer demand will be especially important in reaching the 8% target but is also harder to influence from a government perspective.

China's GDP growth rate is expected to rebound sharply in 2021 after falling to around 2% in 2020 because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but most of that YoY growth will come in the first quarter because Q1 is when China's GDP growth rate fell the most in 2020, and stimulus measures are likely to relax as the year goes on. Q2 GDP growth will still be much higher than in 2020, but most likely only 6 or 7%, rather than the 8 or 9% growth projected for the whole of 2021.

i will use the sd on the annual forecasts (1%point) and apply it to the consensus q forecast (quarterly forecasts by institute are available but not in the easy format i have the yearly numbers in). in a normal year this would introduce too much uncertainty in the quarterly outlook (especially for such "stable" numbers as the chinese economy usually posts) but you could argue that the yearly growth highly depends on what happen in Q2 and how much the world will be normalising by then. all in all 7%+ growth is the likeliest outcome but for the 7-8 bracket, risks are defintely skewed to the downside accross the field of economic forecasters source: focus-economics

Is anyone else unable to find the data at the link provided? I'm putting more confidence in the higher buckets after looking at this more closely. Q2 of 2020 was not as bad for China as Q1, but it was definitely lower over the previous year than is typical. This leaves a lot of room for growth in Q2 since Q2 2020 is a lower baseline. I looked at numbers a couple different ways. One method was to see how Q2 of a typical year compares to Q3 of the previous year. The lowest of these comparisons was 3.45% growth in 2019. If I assume Q2 of 2021 is 3.45% larger than Q3 of 2020 that would put Q2 of 2020 at about 10.10% higher than Q2 of 2019. I also checked based on 2 year growth trends for typical years to estimate what Q2 of 2021 might be using Q2 of 2019. A conservative look at that still puts Q2 of 2021 at around 8.3% growth. One thing to be careful of is that the numbers I'm using are nominal, or not adjusted for inflation. I believe most of the time the real GDP growth is used, which is inflation adjusted. If China reports real GDP growth for quarterly numbers then my estimates could likely be higher than what China would report. Hopefully I can figure out how to see their reported quarterly growth rates to compare and see what kind of adjustment I should make for that. This is one of the biggest factors making me uncertain right now. The other is the possibility of a new coronavirus wave that depresses economic activity in Q2 of 2021. But overall I'm fairly confident in higher numbers. The OECD expects 8% annual growth for China in 2021 (real). That's not super useful for figuring out what Q2 might be because Q1 will have a large amount of growth since Q1 of 2020 was very bad. But since Q2 of 2020 wasn't great either I would guess 8% is a fair rough estimate, or at least helps support some of the rough estimating I'm doing. China GDP data with some rough estimates: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1znPsbGpPwrgZrtv7z5ZNG6NT9OZgGtRk4sSv7JbmyWk/edit?usp=sharing Source for China quarterly GDP data: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CHNGDPNQDSMEI China OECD estimate of 2021 annual growth rate of 8% (real): https://www.oecd.org/economic-outlook/#gdp-projections

In re-looking at my initial forecast - my original estimate of 69% likelihood for "5%-6% growth" presumed too much certainty about the historical numbers being replicated in 6 months.
I have no inside dope into the PBC or other government organs to have that degree of initial certainly.
So I spread out the possibilities - and will wait like everyone else for events to unfold, and for hints to be dropped.
But my bias is clearly is "north of 6%" now that 2 vaccines are available, and inoculations have started - dismal present reports notwithstanding - estimates/expectations of global growth and Chinese domestic growth probably supports the "at least 6%" or "at minimum no worse that recent historical performance" proposition
Pent up demand will probably make the quarter GDP jump.  Much will depend on the CCPs ability to localize containment on the virus.

Recently pre-covid seems to have been pretty consistent at just above 6% and I think the covid drop has now annualised out. I suspect equal upside and downside risk is appropriate given Covid and a fairly flat probability distribution.

Adjusting downwards minimally, as I think that the new Covid strain may lead to a further downtown over the next 1-2 months, which will likely also hit China at least indirectly. Still I think the upper buckets are also absolutely in play, given that the Q3 2020 had a growth of roughly 1%-1.5% higher against the previous Q2 compared to Q3s 2019 and 2018. With Q4s and Q1s regularly being stronger growth quarters at around 2%, this may already put us beyond 6% even before any further Q2 growth. Then again, uncertainty is quite high, especially in these times.

With new data sources coming to my attention, IMF predicting in October 2020 a 8.2% GDP growth for China in 2021 and the World Bank predicting in June 2020 a 6.9% growth in 2021, I will be decreasing my bullish prediction on more than 8% to a 10% (from 25%).  I still think that relative to a weak second quarter 2020 the relative increase of more than 8% stands at least a 10% chance of happening.
Current overal 2021 forecasts are +7.5%-9% However, Q2 2020 may have been especially strong given bounce-back from Q1 shutdowns, so y-on-y may be slightly depressed for Q2 2021

Chinese GDP growth has been decreasing from the roaring 200s, and was able to profit from export growth globally.
China has tried to forward its domestic economy in recent years, and this will help support growth in 2021 as global growth recovers.
But I don't think it will likely yield excess 6% growth as the more conservative 5%-6% growth, when I look at the recent historical data:
https://tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual
Right or wrong - that's my best guess for the moment

China largely makes these numbers up or at best fudges them to agree with growth targets more closely. The current PRC year on year growth target is 6.5%. Suspecting that actual growth will be lower and will be so for the foreseeable future due to the pandemic. Further growth targets of 5% are being proposed for 2021-2025. I suspect party leaders will be eager to show agreement with lower growth targets and regardless of whether numbers are higher or lower in reality will ensure the numbers do not deviate from newly stated PRC targets too much. Between 5 and 6% is most likely. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-economy-target/china-considers-5-annual-gdp-growth-target-for-next-five-years-sources-idUSKBN27L0RE
High export reliance - will limit growth as other countries seek to tackle the pandemic
Year over year growth should be high, since 2nd quarter 2020 was horrible at negative 11%
https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3113377/china-debt-local-government-default-risk-grows-authorities All's not as well as it seems

Base effects would imply that to get back to a trend rate of 5.5% you would need just over 8.35% growth. Given the liquidity injection by the worlds central banks and a global vaccine rollout, there is no reason why this would not be achievable. It is possible that faster growth is concentrated more into H2 or that the authorities might prefer to smooth the growth trajectory a bit, so I have allocated an 82% chance equally above 7%.

China doubling its growth in the second quarter of 2021 seems reasonable, especially given the suppressed rate in 2020 due to COVID. I don't expect this rate to land much higher than double, however, given that China is an export economy and the health of its importer economies is in question for 2021, given both the lagged and persistent effects of COVID in the western economies.
The outcome depends on how powerful the Biden admin will be in passing stimulus bills.

Looks like the forecast in the Economist article mentioned in the description just extrapolates the recent trend into the future (see the straight lines in the figure). With the most recent numbers (https://tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual)
you could calculate for example: Most recent trend 2020: Q3 - Q2 = 4.9 - 3.2 = 1.7 (growth of the growth rate per quarter) 2020 Q4 : 4.9 + 1 * 1.7 = 6.6
2021 Q1 : 4.9 + 2 * 1.7 = 8.3
2021 Q2 : 4.9 + 3 * 1.7 = 10
and so on, leading to an average growth rate of approximately 11 % in 2021. But how much is such a forecast worth? Looking at the past values (https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG?locations=CN) it seems that
the GDP growth is very cloudlike and certainly not linear. Especially in times of a global
pandemic. This leads me to an uncertain prediction with a small bet on recovery (reach of the old
6-7 % growth before the pandemic).

Completely reversing direction. The Q2 growth next year will be compared to Q2 GDP this year, which was depressed by coronavirus. Initially I was thinking only of China's growth projections, which have been that growth is slowing down and make 5 to 6% the more likely target. But using Q2 of this year as the baseline makes it very easy to hit high growth next year. Will update in a few days once I've had a chance to do some more research.
Return to pre COVID growth should result in approximate y/y growth rate of 7.9% for Q2 2021
Covid affected q2 ‘20 and underlying growth remains

Assuming the data out of China can be trusted, the growth over the last 40 years  growth in GDP has maxed at around 15% and min around 3% to 5%. A higher base and fewer lower hanging fruits makes this development harder and harder to maintain, even if the comparison Q2 2020 was lower than normal (3.2%) I do not take it for granted that growth on growth is a walk in the park. Thus, 6% seems a fair baseline for a normal year.  What could push the growth up from the baseline? Demand for export articles such as masks and sanitizers will likely still be high, but as Q2 2020 already has CV19 this will likely not make a big difference. Domestically, China can still pump out investment in infrastructure and digitization but hard to say when China will reach breaking point when it comes to the debt. However, YoY comparison will be vs. 3.2% growth in Q2 2020, which should make it somewhat easier to achieve growth i.e. maybe more like 7% growth.  On the downside, lower growth from export markets such as the EU or the US could pull down the growth, however, unlikely that this is much worse than Q2 2020. I am also assuming that China will use the centralized control to enforce rules to prevent spread of virus even after Chinese New Year celebrations.
from q2 onwards companies must best their corona help boosted previous quarters. will be difficult to beat

Simulations:
_From historical data (excluding 2020), I estimated the change in growth rate over time (simple linear regression)
_Simulated 100k events with some uncertainty in the parameters and counted how often the result falls in the respective range. I also systematically added 1 point to the result, due to unusually high growth expectations in 2021 after slow growth in 2020. Note: This 1 point is of course arbitrary and I will update as new numbers arrive. Links:
_China's economy expected to hold up well in 2021 and might be unsually high due to Covid https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/17/chinas-economy-will-hold-up-well-in-the-coming-year
https://www.reuters.com/article/china-economy-poll-idUSKBN27C0QB
Expect lower end of 6-7% based on historical trends. Extremes feel less likely due to state interventions in the statistics
Experts (IMF et al) coming in between 6 and 7 points.

China's GDP growth has been falling for years as the economy matures and the easy gains have been made. I expect this trend to continue, especially as the world will still be affected by COVID. Politically it is difficult for China to report steep falls in GDP so the most likely outcome is a continuation of the current gradual decline
Distributing around 5. My understanding is growth has been slowing in China even aside from the pandemic, so I see higher numbers as unlikely. Preliminary forecast until I do more research.

Update. Another correction.  It seems that there is considerably more pessimism about the speed of the recovery in China than I'd expected. Comparing the pandemic to the Great Depression or to the Great Recession and inferring something about the persistence of the shock this way seems quite wrongheaded to me. The persistence of the unemployment figures is much less this time around, and I see no reason to be too pessimistic about the prospects of a speedy recovery.  Still, I'm increasing the probability of the %6 to %7 range to account for the general pessimism in the forecast, which may reflect some knowledge I'm not privy to. I also think the scale of the probabilities in my previous forecast was wrong - I don't think it's reasonable to say that growth between %5 and %6 is more than half as likely as growth between %6 and %7.
Small correction by hand to be more mindful of tail risks in the forecast not included in the regression model.
Bounce back exports as end of pandemic comes into view

The crowd forecast is seriously ignoring the regression to the trend in GDP growth. Even a regression to the trend of the past 8 years decaying exponentially at a geometric rate 1/3 per year is enough to push the odds for over %8 growth over %50, and it's likely this hypothesis is too pessimistic.

As a baseline, official Chinese statistics tend to be inflated or at least massaged.  This is widely recognized by economists.  However, the Chinese economy has recovered from COVID sooner than others because it was affected first and did nothing to stop the infection from spreading to other countries.  In 2Q 2021, the rest of the world is likely to start coming out of recession, which likely will increase demand for Chinese exports.  This may fuel additional production in China, and tighten supply and labor there.  Given the historic average in China of about 6% reported growth, there is a good chance the increase will be higher than that y-o-y.
It's more difficult to predict the true number, but the reported statistic will most certainly be over 8%.
High 7s/low 8s seems very likely given the weak Q2 20 base and strong Q3 20 number already "booked", although some tail risk for e.g. a renewed outbreak.
Comparison is against the GDP from the pandanemic.

The Economist suggests that a growth rate of 8% would "surprise no one," since the comparison is against the artificially depressed GDP from the pandemic: https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/17/chinas-economy-will-hold-up-well-in-the-coming-year Bloomberg similarly predicts 8% growth next year, followed by a target of 5% for the next few years: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-05/china-considering-5-year-growth-target-of-about-5-reuters-says Some quick math to validate this: China's growth rate was previously holding steady at around 6%, but the pandemic slowed their Q2 growth this year to 3.2%. They seem have shrugged off the pandemic with little damage, so if their GDP catches up to its previous trendline, Q2 2021 growth will be above 8%. I think the crowd forecast is currently ignoring the impact of this catch-up growth.
the actual data might be well above 7% but in order to demonstrate a smooth curve , the official release number would be around 7%

Consensus and IMF forecast suggests somewhere between 8 and 8.5% for 2021. Based on history and considering Covid uncertainty, 0.5 to 1% shift either way from expected growth should be about one standard deviation.

China is export oriented. The Pandemic create many difficulties on population other countries to be willing to consume by optimism. Therefore the demand is lower by importing countries. The economic world war caused by sitting President of USA suppressed also economic welfare by trading interactions between China and many other countries. The RECP will have only a small effect 2021, because momentarily the middle class is too small at trading partners of China. The domestic consumption is increasing in China and is a plus for growth. Overall there is a BIP increase but generally lower than before the pandemic.

China's GDP growth averaged just over 6% per quarter for more than six quarters preceding their COVID shutdown at the beginning of 2020. Now they are recovering to pre-pandemic levels, and by second quarter 2021 they should return to this approximate level. There is a small chance they may exceed pre-pandemic levels as the rest of the world economy recovers as COVID vaccines become more readily available. There is also somewhat of a chance a new strain of the virus will emerge, which causes China's GDP growth to dip below 5% in 2d qtr 2021.

The Chinese economy has been trending downward for a while now, and the pandemic greatly affected Q1 growth as it did pretty much everywhere else later in Q2. China has been bouncing back since then, but it remains to be seen how policy under President-elect Biden might affect this.  My prediction is that, with the hope of a vaccine to COVID-19 by the beginning of 2021, the economy in China will bounce back to pre-COVID levels, but it will be too early for changes in U.S./China relations to have any affect on this. https://tradingeconomics.com/china/gdp-growth-annual
